Award.AwardTitle: RAPID/Collaborative Research: Investigating Unanticipated Geotechnical Phenomena in Kumamoto, Japan, Observed from the April 2016 Earthquake Sequence

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative U.S.-Japan Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) award will investigate unanticipated and poorly understood geotechnical phenomena observed following the April 2016 Kumamoto earthquake sequence (KES) in Japan. The Geotechnical Extreme Events Reconnaissance (GEER) organization mobilized a U.S. reconnaissance team to explore the affected area immediately following the KES. The U.S. team in collaboration with Japanese investigators identified significant case histories that warrant further investigation due to their unique, unanticipated, and poorly understood nature, as well as their important potential implications for seismic design and safety in the U.S. and around the world. These case histories include, among other things: an unexplained 10km-long depression zone within the Mount Aso volcano caldera that caused significant damage to structures and transmission lines; a fault rupture through the spillway of a large dam impounding a full reservoir; and surprisingly limited observations of soil liquefaction and its effects for an earthquake of this size and apparent site conditions. This RAPID award supports a detailed study of the underlying causes behind these observations through: (1) the use of state-of-the-art remote sensing techniques to collect perishable surface topology, soil deformation, and structure settlement or tilt information from known liquefaction and major landslide sites; (2) the collection of preliminary geotechnical, seismic, geologic, and topographic information from potential case history sites of interest; and (3) the performance of a comprehensive set of laboratory tests on retrieved samples followed by preliminary simulations to evaluate the soil's resistance to liquefaction and response under cyclic loading. In doing so, this award contributes to the state of knowledge and practice in critical areas of geotechnical earthquake engineering and hence, the resilience of geotechnical structures and infrastructure globally. Collaboration with Japanese researchers through this study will improve the relationship and cooperation between the two countries, and will provide valuable international research experience for the PIs and the graduate students involved in this project.

This grant will advance the science and practice of geotechnical earthquake engineering by enhancing the fundamental understanding of seismic-induced ground deformations and liquefaction triggering. This RAPID project will enable the collection of valuable and perishable information related to landslides, liquefaction triggering and effects, and earthquake-induced ground deformations from the 2016 KES in Japan. There are a number of phenomena observed after the KES that cannot be explained by the existing state of knowledge or current analytical and/or empirical prediction models. These phenomena could have important implications for seismic design in locations with similar geology and geomorphology in the U.S. Information collected from the affected sites followed by laboratory testing and analysis will increase our understanding of the underlying causes of the geotechnical phenomena observed following the KES, which will ultimately impact the state of geotechnical earthquake engineering practice. The engineering community will benefit from learning why soil liquefaction did not occur to the extent that it was predicted in this region. Joint application of 3D digital surface modeling using UAV-based aerial photography and terrestrial LiDAR techniques will advance the science and art of remote sensing in geotechnical engineering and will improve the way surficial evidence of geotechnical earthquake phenomena is collected. Further, preliminary field and laboratory data collected from this RAPID will guide and inspire a larger international collaborative research effort to more thoroughly investigate the observed unique geotechnical phenomena and damage from this series of earthquakes.

Outcome Report:

The major goals of this RAPID study included:

1) Identify potential sites of interest as they pertain to the occurrence or non-occurrence of soil liquefaction following the April 2016 Kumamoto earthquake sequence; 2) Collect preliminary geotechnical, topographical, hydrological, and geophysical data from these potential sites of interest; 3)Assess our current ability to correctly predict the occurrence and non-occurrence of liquefaction and its effects at the sites of interest through insitu SPT and CPT testing, lab testing of retrieved samples, insitu shear wave velocity profile testing, and engineering analysis of this data using conventional methods; 4) Identify the gaps in our knowledge and understanding based on findings from this study. The significant outcomes and findings resulting from this work are summarized as follows:

Intellectual Merit

Detailed geotechnical (SPT and CPT) and geophysical (SASW) testing were performed at four carefully selected sites in Kumamoto, and index testing was performed on all samples. Results from this testing revealed that soils from the Kumamoto plain are rich in moderate-to-high plasticity fines from the nearby Aso volcano. Soils that were susceptible to liquefaction according to conventional compositional criteria were close to liquefying under cyclic triaxial testing that we performed, but did not actually liquefy. However, conventional simplified methods for liquefaction initation showed the widespread prediction of liquefaction in the SPT and CPT logs that we developed. A thorough literature review in both American and Japanese sources focusing on soil mechanics of volcanic sediments revealed several likely reasons for the lack of soil liquefaction from the Kumamoto event:

1) Volcanic soils, particularly those containing halloycite and allophane, depending on the region and depositional type, may contain properties of soil crushability. Additional laboratory testing should be performed to better understand the soil before correlations are applied.

2) Volcanic soils can quickly weather into fine clay material with high plasticity.

3) Volcanic soils may contain higher levels of organic components than traditional soils.

In addition, we observed that differences between Japanese standards for visual classification of soils and American standards for visual classification of soils resulted in the mis-identification of liquefaction-susceptible soils. Care should be taken to understand classification schemes and practices for foreign nations.

Significant findings regarding the depression zone in the Aso Crater were identified. Our team located numerous evidences of soil compression in the field, supporting the theory that the depression zone is a massive seismic sliding block feature that is approximately 10 km long by 4 km wide. Application of a new multi-directional seismic slope displacement methdology successfully replicated the observed deformations from the depression zone.

Broader Impacts

This study successfully brought together American and Japanese researchers to understand a poorly understood phenomenon. Collaboration between the PIs, Professor Kaz Konegai, and our students provided valuable research and networking experiences for students and strengthened academic relations between our institutions and our countries. Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) flights and the resulting 3D models of the many of the damaged sites provides a valuable tool that can be used globally to educate individuals of all ages regarding the damage that occurred from the Kumamoto event. The resulting 3D models also continue to serve as valuable research tools that are being used to measure ground deformations from the earthquake. This project also provided Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) funding for an undergraduate student, which resulted in his pursuing and successfully completing a M.S. degree in civil engineering performing research related to the project. The project ultimately resulted in one M.S. thesis, four peer-reviewed conference papers, and two journal manuscripts that are currently under preparation.
